author: Phils Phindings

text: Idk, this game is awesome or is overrated? I need you sugestion.
author: Angeal Astral

text: @Angeal Astral Well all in all it is a high quality game, with for the time, great graphics, an excellent soundtrack and  sympathetic core characters. Main complaints about it are usually the high character count (which you can't collect in one playthrough), a sometimes repetitive nature (Fort Dragonia multiple playthroughs) and the little connection to the more popular predecessor. I still recommend playing Chrono Trigger first so you can appreciate these connections to the fullest.

text: I feel like I need to give this game more of a chance. I was never really into it all that much. I absolutely love the music, that much is for sure. Yasunori Mitsuda is one of my favorite composers of all time, if not my absolute favorite, but in terms of the game itself, I didn't enjoy what I played. However, I'm nearing the end of my first full playthrough of Chrono Trigger now after years of playing it but never beating it, so maybe when I finally put that game to rest, I can try to get back into this one at full force, because I definitely want to see how the story plays out.

author: Tano Diaz

text:
There was a period of time, stretching between FF6 on the SNES to Skies of Arcadia on the Dreamcast when J-rpgs were just so damn good! Grandia, FF-Anything, Chrono-Cross, Shining Force 3, and a ton of others that I have for my Playstation1.¬†
Not being critical of current stuff, but damn they just kicked so much butt back then, devs were in the zone!
author: Michael Dougherty

text: I completely agree with you 100%. I constantly want to rewind back to the days of PS1 J-rpgs.

text: Xenoblade chronicles gives me hope of the future.

text: its cuz all the stupid technology now every stupid kid want "graphycs" and they dont care about OST story or other stuff like old times...
author: Bayonetta

text: +Michael Dougherty It was probably because they didn't have access to the super fancy ultra graphics that we have today. So they were forced to rely more on storytelling and characterization. Once Final Fantasy went 3D, then they focused more on the graphics, and not as much on the story.
author: Ashelm56

text: +Sinbad Kaminari I think similarly, but I think it's developers think that's what we want. By trying to appeal to a more massive player base with flashiness and prettiness, they lost ability to focus more on the life and character of the game. It's an absolute shame because the mid-90s was gold.
author: Carolyn

text: It's true that people want graphics these days and don't care about story. But the problem is JRPG's also lack in the story deparment these days. They are filled with tons of cliche's
author: ShineSpark 88

text:
I used to have a puggy!

On topic though... I'm telling you guys. It's the evil corporations being corporationy. Games have become the fastest money maker in entertainment to date now. LOTTA money to be made in this industry. The greedy fuck headed toms have caught wind of the smell of video game cash. That sweet call of duty money. That sweet mmo money. That sweet micro transaction and dlc money. They want as MUCH as possible without putting up much effort to get it.

That's why the fuck your games suck more than they did about 20 years ago.
author: Soyborne. Born, made, and undone by the soy.

text:
That's because back then, Developers actually poured their hearts and souls into their work most of the time instead of just creating mindless shovelwear and graphical revamps of what they've already made. Yes, that still exists today. But, it's a little less apparent nowadays. Though you can find games that still have the hearts and souls of their developers in them. Games that looked as though they were painstakingly made.

Though that era also had that, there was a bit more quality control too.
author: Aduro Tri

text: Kayne Woolley That hope died with the next two Xenoblade games. T.T
author: Green Kirby

text: The only like really good JRPG‚Äôs from more modern day in my opinion is the Persona Games and NieR Automata, Unless you could count Zelda as a JRPG too since it is a rpg made in Japan because Breath of the Wild is amazing.
author: Xander

text: It's partly because games are so expensive to make now, actually. The developers still care just as much, but the money needs to come from somewhere, and the people who give the money often don't know much about or care much about games. They call the shots even though they have no idea what they're doing, and pull "mass appeal" from popular games, trying to jam mechanics it into places that they don't fit. They can also change stuff at the last minute, which I imagine wreaks havoc on development.

author: Dave Bobenchik

text:
What was the start of all this?
   When did the cogs of fate begin to turn?
   
   Perhaps it is impossible to grasp that answer now,
   From deep within the flow of time...
   
   But, for a certainty, back then,
   We loved so many, yet hated so much,
   We hurt others and were hurt ourselves...
   
   Yet even then, we ran like the wind,
   Whilst our laughter echoed,
   Under cerulean skies...

author: Frank

text: There are things called "Let's Play", which allow you to enjoy a video game without playing it, if gameplay is so boring to you. Secondly, any game can be boring if you play it wrong. I play the MGS series, for example, aiming for a No Kill/No Alert game every time, and it's satisfying to see that Big Boss rank at the end. Or Super Mario World, I speed-rush every exit with minimal Cape/Yoshi usage, just for fun's sake. That said, a good plot makes you care about why you are playing, not how.
author: JeramiahWindsor

text: Then you're missing out.
author: pseudogenesis

text: What could you possibly find so thrilling about a bonsai tree that MGS lacks? I assume you tried playing the first one, correct? Granted it's not the best game in the series, but it's necessary for the PLOT, which is by far the strongest selling point of the series. The story is fantastic. If you play games purely for gameplay, then you'll be unable to appreciate the true gems sitting at the top of a pile of rubbish.
author: pseudogenesis

text: "you had to hide in the shadows killing people like a coward and it was just plain dumb." It's called a stealth game, you idiot. It says "Tactical Espionage Action" right on the box. All this proves is that you don't have the attention span to get an hour into the game without dropping it.

text:
Fuckin' game is DANK~!!!!!!!!! I miss the days of when I played games for the first time, it's just so magical~ T.T
When I got this, I was 8-10 years old, I think~ I was in New Hampshire visitin' family with my Ma an' Dadda, an' we went to the Flea Market to say bye to my Nan. So I'm lookin' around, an' this guy had a stand COVERED in video games~ X3 Well, I had to pick between this and Final Fantasy Tactics, guess what I chose~ X3 I ogled that bitch the entire 4 hour ride back home to Maine~ X3

I don't know why, but this song is the ONLY part of Chrono Cross that I don't like that much. I like the game, the story, the characters (all ~40 of them), the villains, the soundtrack (mostly), the battle system, the bosses, the dungeons (especially Chronopolis), but not this song.

Well, not that much, it's still good.
